title: Digital Detox Rebound Effect
context: People overwhelmed by screen time and social media take digital detoxes — weekend phone fasts, social media breaks, tech-free vacations. The wellness industry promotes these as resets. Initial results feel transformative: better sleep, more presence, reduced anxiety. But detoxes treat symptoms without addressing the structural dependencies that created the problem. When the detox ends, people return to the same digital environment with the same design patterns optimized for engagement. Usage often rebounds to higher levels than before, as accumulated notifications, messages, and FOMO create a binge-purge cycle that mirrors disordered eating patterns.
hypothesis: Taking a break from technology resets your relationship with screens.

chain.root: Person takes a digital detox break

children.label: Person attributes all problems to technology
Guilt from binge triggers another detox — cycle begins
Work requires digital tools — full disconnection impossible

dontIf: You're using detoxes as a substitute for changing your daily digital habits
You expect a weekend break to undo months of compulsive usage patterns
ifYouMust: Combine detox with permanent environmental changes (app deletions, notification settings)
Gradually reduce usage rather than going cold turkey
Address the underlying needs that technology fills (boredom, loneliness, anxiety)

alternatives.name: Digital minimalism
alternatives.note: Permanently restructure technology use around values, not periodic abstinence

alternatives.name: Environment design
alternatives.note: Remove triggers (notifications, home screen apps) rather than willpower-based abstinence

alternatives.name: Intentional usage schedules
alternatives.note: Designated times for social media rather than all-or-nothing

falsifiability: Digital detoxes produce lasting reductions in screen time beyond 30 days post-detox
Post-detox usage does not exceed pre-detox levels in the first week back
Periodic detoxes are as effective as permanent habit changes for long-term wellbeing

seo.description: Digital detoxes spike post-break usage by 20-30% as accumulated FOMO creates binge-purge cycles. Behavior returns to baseline within 2-4 weeks without structural changes.
